The appellant contended that the moratorium could also be imposed by a resolution of the appellant PCI and it would be a law as per Article 13 of the Constitution. The respondent contended that unless there is an approval of the Central Government with regard to the moratorium, the same would not be valid in law. The issue for determination before the Supreme Court was: Whether the moratorium, as imposed by the Central Council of the appellant PCI, could have been imposed by the said Resolution, which is in the nature of an executive instruction of the Central Council? Answering in the negative, the Supreme Court Held: Moratorium in present case was issued by the Central Council of the appellant PCI in its executive powers and not by framing any regulation, as provided under Sections 10 and 18 of the Pharmacy Act, 1948. (Para 32) With regard to the establishment of educational institutions, three articles of the Constitution come into play. Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution gives the right to all the citizens to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business; this right is subject to restrictions that may be placed under Article 19(6) of the Constitution. Article 26 of the Constitution the right to every religious denomination to establish and maintain an institution for religious purposes, which would include an educational institution. Article 19(1 )(g) and Article 26 of the Constitution, therefore, confer rights on all citizens and religious denominations to establish and maintain educational institutions. (Para 34) T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. Such a right is subject to the laws imposing reasonable restrictions in the interest of the general public. Laws may be enacted for prescribing the professional or technical qualifications necessary for practising any profession or carrying on any occupation, trade or business. However, the question that requires to be answered is as to whether the same can be done by executive instructions or not. (Para 41) Establishment and management of an educational institution has been held to be a part of fundamental right being a right of occupation as envisaged under Article 19(1 )(g) of the Constitution. A citizen cannot be deprived of the said right except in accordance with law. The requirement oflaw for the purpose of clause (6) of Article 19 of the Constitution can by no stretch of imagination be achieved by issuing a circular or a policy decision in terms of Article 162 of the Constitution or otherwise. GAVAI, J.- Leave granted in all the special leave petitions. The appeals filed by the Pharmacy Council of India (hereinafter referred to as "PCI") mainly challenge the: (i) judgments dated 9-11-2021 1, 2, 3, passed by the Division Bench of the High Court of Kamataka at Bengaluru in Writ Appeals Nos. 746-748 of 2020; (ii) judgment dated 7-3-2022, passed by the learned Single Judge of the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi in Shaheed Teg Bhadur College of Pharmacy v. Pharmacy Council of India4 ; and (iii) judgment dated 22-4-2022, passed by the learned Single Judge of the High Court of Chhattisgarh at Bilaspur in Chouksey College of Pharmacy v. Pharmacy Council of India 5 . Several interim orders6, 7 , 8, 9, 10 passed by these courts during the pendency of these matters are also subject to challenge in some of the appeals. They are also being disposed of by the present judgment. 2.
